choices.text:
ruling out democracy. This has been done through the implementation of an authoritarian system that limits the exercise of democracy to parties that adhere blindly to rule by a single party “socialist” state. In the last two decades, these parties have managed to silence many voices that question the current social and economic situation of the country and whose analyses do not necessarily align with the governing party’s views. This censorship has been accomplished by banning presentations of critical authors and propagating inaccurate information about authors and their analyses. It has also manifested itself through the complete exclusion of discussions and participation from populations that think differently.

Over the two decades since the end of “democracy”, Ecuador has descended from the 34th position in the Economic Freedom Report 2017 to 101. Ecuador is now considered a “Moderate Regime” — a country in which government corruption, nepotism and the authoritarian grip on the media and so on is still in place. However, because there are elements of freedom of expression and free elections, it falls into that designation.

América Latina23 mediates between academics and the public, giving researchers the opportunity to share their expertise while promoting a greater understanding of issues relevant to Latin America. We are closing the gap between academia and civil society, while encouraging citizens to participate and debate through open access publications, reports, commentaries, podcasts, and book reviews.
